posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
When I tried it on my phone, it showed multiple options in the selector at
once. I think I've fixed that by having it adjust the label's height based off
of the current layout height. Actually haven't tried it on my phone yet. So
we'll see!
posts.title: Now selector selects one at a time.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've made a scroll view based selector. It's not perfect, but it does have the
inertia that will make the user experience just that much nicer.
posts.title: Inertia! I mastered it!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Turns out I forgot a requirement in the buildozer spec. It works now.
As does the new saving feature. I'm pleased with tonight's progress.
posts.title: Got it working on android again.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Should be able to save and load sessions now.
posts.title: I think I've fixed the saving!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: I also fixed the wrapping issue and started work on saving. But now it crashes.
posts.title: You can now edit drinks.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I fixed the negative BAC. Not only was that being kinda silly, that app could tell you that you had a BAC of zero or less immediately after drinking your n>1 drink. So it screwed with the accuracy. I just had it bottom out. So if a drink says it's going to give you < 0 BAC, it gives you 0.

I moved the BAC total to the bottom and added a naming field on the main screen. I'll look into the momentum on the ABV and OZ selectors. I think it can be done, but just didn't get to it tonight. The other thought I had was to give a dial to each digit. Which I'll do if I can't give it momentum.

The drink list now comes down with an animation. It's a bit dramatic and silly, but I so I can tone it down. I just felt like doing something fun. I believe I have fixed the squishing issue. And if I haven't fixed it sufficiently I can easily up the size of the drinks listed. I darkened the drink list background. Drinks now have an edit button and a delete button. Delete works, edit doesn't. I got stuck on some formatting issues or I might have been able to get edit to work.
posts.title: UI updates mostly.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I'll have Kennan look over the app and tell me what he thinks. I
think it will hit a fair bit of his initial requirements. But there
is much to be improved. Firstly, and most obviously to him, will be
the fact that it is designed for a tablet not a phone. So I'll need
to reconfigure the layout to get it to work better on a smaller
display. The ability to remove drinks would also be valuable, and
edit them. In case you enter some wrong info or remembered another
drink and want to add it later.
posts.title: Got a alpha version out!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Actually with this commit I'm basically in alpha. The app as a whole
is a relatively simple thing so it didn't take much to get basic
functionality up and running. It will take a little yet to get it
polished, but I should have something for Kennan later today.
posts.title: Initial commit and start of program.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Initial commit
posts.title: Initial commit

gduel.description: A game of gravity bomb lobbing.
gduel.name: Gravity Duel

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I added a makefile. For some reason buildozer won't compile the apk
on my NFS drive. I must copy the code to my physical drive and then
it will build properly. So the make file is just a save of that set
of copy functions. And then some where to remember the actual build
call to buildozer.
posts.title: oooh, two commits in one night!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I got so carried away with the debugging last time that I forgot
to commit. woops. oh well. So what have I done tonight?

Well, tonight specifically I haven't done too much. I got the
settings to work properly. This is good as it allows the game to be
playable again on handhelds. It wasn't work for a while as a result
of the config not finding necessary values.

Last time I coded I accomplished quite a number of things. I got
the settings screen up and running, if not fully working. I fixed
the issue where red wouldn't be able to fire until they recalled
their torpedoes at the begining of the game. Shots that collide or
fall into the sun now get removed from the counter. When you start
a new game, the previous shots are removed, clearing the gamefield.
And I added a score keeper. I'm intending to add a "first to x"
game mode in the rules, so this puts down one of the needed
components of that.

Left to do:
Add an icon.
First to x matches
ship selector
nicer ships
explosion on ship destroyed
sound

which honestly isn't a particularly long list! Hopefully I'll have
something up in the app store here soon. w00t w00t!
posts.title: I forgot to commit last time.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I did not get as much done as I had hoped I would. I have a managed
to get the game seperated out into screens now. That helps. You can
start a new game and it will throw up a victory screen and then
you can go back to the menu or play again. Progress to be sure.

What I'm slightly annoyed with is my lack of progress on the
settings front. I was trying to get the settings screen to work
and I just didn't quite get it because I couldn't figure out how
to get config to behave. And I need to go empty the litter box now
before going to bed. Hopefully I'll be able to accomplish more
later this week.
posts.title: Slow progress tonight.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I have added trails to the ships and torpedoes. It makes the game
much prettier and gives a better sense of movement seeing the trail
of the objects flying around. It makes the game feel like it is
actually a legit game and not some high school project.

Torpedoes now collide with each other, so you can theoretically
protect yourself from an incoming torpedo, though it would be
pretty spectacular if you did. I imagine it could work well for
spray and pray on an incoming torpedo.

The system for firing torpedoes is greatly simplified. But I did it
in a way that should allow for some fun later. I've got it set now
that you have one fire button and one recall button. This allows
you to just have a panic button that kills your own torpedoes
should you be about to kill yourself. The number of torpedoes will
also be something that can be edited.

I've made a burn down chart. 11 items on it before I can make an
initial release of the game onto the android play store. I hope to
do so in just a few more weeks like this one.
posts.title: Trails and Tuuuuuuuuuuuuuuubes!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've fix the launch speed of the torpedoes so they actually feel
shot now rather than just kinda rolled out of your ship. You can
start a new game immediately upon your current game ending,also it
provides a little note about who the winner is. Flipped the player
1 controller so it would be oriented correctly for tablet between
player game style.
posts.title: Much improved!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've setup the buildozer file and renaimed duel.py to main.py
becuase I'm comptent and totally know that buildozer needs your
code to be in main.py. But Tried it with wife, was funny. Needs
a fair bit of tweeking, but the bones are there and great.
posts.title: Buildozing!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I have achieved minimum viable product on this app. I'm going to
now try to load it up as an android app and see if my wife and I
can play it.

You can: Naviaget your ship, shoot torpedos, crash into the sun,
blow your opponent away, and blow your self away. You can also
shoot an unlimited number of torpedos and you can't self destruct
them. So this should be an interesting few games.
posts.title: Minimum viable product

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I am nearing on a minimum viable product. Things done today:

1. Joystick multi touch
I'll have to back port these to the original joystick repo. I have
fixed the problem where the joysticks would all respond to the same
touch as soon as that touch moved. Now the joysticks keep track of
what touch touched them and only respond to it.

2. Joystick mahts:
I've added into the joystick class the maths for all that you could
want from the joystick. Now, not only can you get the pad_x and
pad_y as percent of total range, you can also get the angle,
radians, and magnitude of the joystick. This allows you to work
with it in what ever form you desire.

3. Ship rotation.
4. Ship thursters.
5. sun collision.
6. started on torpedos.
Not finished yet, but I've started working on torpedoes. They are
currently having issues of being fired from not your ship. But I
have an idea on what could be causing that problem. The layout.

Lots done today! but now I need to research dancing for my friend's
wedding. Busy life right now. busy life.
posts.title: A dramatic step forward.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Name is probably taken, but it will be fine for a working title.
Game play is basic: Two ships in orbit around a sun. You try to
lob torpedos at each other around the sun. You have thrusters to
get into a better position, but you might just run yourself into
the sun. so be careful with thruster use!

I'm using the kivy Joystick I made the other day. I've already
found a problem with it. Two joysticks at the same time doesn't
work very well. I need them to track which touch they started from.
Mostly the issue is that on_touch_move doesn't check the touch it
recieved to see if it is the same touch as previous.
posts.title: Initial commit of Duel game.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I believe I've got this already now for Kivy Garden. It was a bit
of a thing to try and get the pep8 checker working. I basically
just copied a number of files from the kivy designer over to my
dist-packages directory. I actually had to make the kivy/tools/
pep8checker directory in order to put the files there. It was a bit
of a mess.

But I can finally commit, as you can see. I did also make a few
changes worth noting. I fixed the issue where on touch move would
be picked up by the joystick even if it wasn't the joystick's
touch that moved.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've got a little bit of polishing left to do on the code. Mostly
it will be removing commented code and removing debug print
statements, oh and adding comments for maintainability. But beyond
that it's basically done. Now I need to figure out how to share it
via the Kivy Garden.
posts.title: Finished it! Mostly at least.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I fixed the maths. The main the was that I was assigning it to
the pad's x and y verses pad's center. I also had to deal with a
flipped sign. Basically subtracting the widget's center from the
touch rather than the other way around (despite that being how I
left that).
posts.title: Fixed the maths!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
For a number of games I have planed, I need an onscreen joystick.
So far I have actually managed to get most of the behavior I'm
looking for programmed in. The last piece of behavior that is
needed is what happens when a touch starts inside the joystick area
and moves out. I tried implementing it tonight, but ran into some
bugs. It gets a little funky. Not sure where my math went wrong.

There will also need to be some work done to generalize it a little
more. Right now it basically has to be 200x200. I've put in some
calculations that attempt to deal with arbitrary sizes, but getting
a function joystick has been my first priority of course.
posts.title: Initial commit on Joystick widget.

mccc.description: A collection of scripts for making minecraft buildings with Blender3D
mccc.name: Command Craft

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
With the 1.12 release I've now got a much easier system to deal
with over all I'd say. Functions are super nice. They will really
change how this all works. I just create the model and call the
function.

So now materials are used to decide what a block is. This works with
most things, but not so much for command blocks. Materials have a
maximum length, and commands shoot over that really fast. So I've
got a hackish way of doing it right now with command replacements.
So there is improvements to be had, but the plugin is hardly a
full fledged plugin just yet, and I've got plenty to learn, so all
in all I'd say this is going well. w00t!
posts.title: GREAT progress!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
it did not like facing:up or {facing:up} but it can totally dig
facing=up. Minecraft commands are weird.
posts.title: So it would seem, equality is the key.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I'm going to have the name you give the block change things in the out put of
the fill commmands so you can change the block type easily. Work in progess,
but it is progressing quite nicely. Time for Civ.
posts.title: Started working on transforms.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
There can now be multiple towers. This will allow for bigger and bigger
commands to exist. When your command, currently, gets taller than 50,
it starts a new tower.
posts.title: Multi towers now works.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've made a huge pile of changes with this commit. Pictures have
been added to most of the apps on the apps page. the pictures will
naturallly flow behind the text for each application. I put down
some basic pieces for about and contact, though some tweeking is
still necessary. I've added a discription for each app.

Over all this is really starting to close in on being a fleshed out
website the way have been envisioning/desiring. I'm pleased! Just
a little more and I'll be able to make it public facing.
posts.title: Things are looking good!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I changed all the templates to use inheritance from a base
template, ssg.html. This makes each template just a little bit
simplier and avoids me repeating myself. DRY woohoo!

I also expanded the README.md quite a bit. I explained how the
whole git-posting system works and why I use markdown for the
project pages.

My next work will be in making things a little more fancy. I've
got several ideas written down in my sketch book on how to make the
apps page more exciting. I intend on making each app a kind of
button with text and images inside. But of course automatically
generated so I don't have to bog myself down with creating content
for the website. Let the website create itself!
posts.title: Template inheritance now in use.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've got style actually starting to appear on the website now. I
banged my head against the flask-bootstrap templates for a while
but in the end decided to not use the base templates and instead
create my own. This requires a little more effort, but it allows me
a lot more control. Since HTML is still something I'm trying to
master, keeping it simple is a great help.

I've downloaded a bootstrap css style. I can easily change the
style of my whole site but just swapping these files out. Pretty
neat really! Right now I've just choosen a simple black style. I'm
found of sites that are primarily dark colors, it feels less
straining to look at. As I add pictures and things, it may be less
of a deal and I'll probably switch to a lighter style, but this
works for now.
posts.title: Style is coming!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: I've added the read me for the website's repo. Just space duel left to have a read me. Then each project will have it's own description page.
posts.title: Added README.

app. I'll probably end up doing something more interesting in the
future, but this is certainly a functional first step, something
that allows me to get this website up sooner than later.

I've also re-arranged things a bit. I've moved my git-post/posts.py
file into utility-scripts/ folder. It and copy-markdown.py are the
occupants of my new utility-scripts folder. These are scripts I'll
have to run periodically for now to get the data to show.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
A small fix, but I have updated the pathing for resources. While
resource/projects.json worked fine for the dev enviorment, it was
failing in production. So I added a bit that I found on stack
overflow: https://stackoverflow.com/q/14825787

This introduced me to getting the location of the current file and
saving it as APP_ROOT. This should work in both dev and prod.
posts.title: APP_ROOT

posts.message:

over to the devlog tab like it supposed to be. I'll do write ups
for the apps section probably next. Those to will probably also be
automated deally bobs. I think I'll use the README.md files for
that. This way I can maintain a nice summary page while in the
code as usual. I'll probably have this whole site automated by the
time I actually feel like publishing it. xD

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I got the posts.py file working like I want it to now. Turns out
there was a trailing '\n' causing all the problems. But I decided
to upgrade the repos file to use json so I could add more info to
the projects.

In looking at this, I might release this as it's own project in the
future. Autoblogging via git commit messages is pretty knifty and
I think more people than just me would enjoy it. We'll see. Right
now I'm jsut happy to get all the projects in to the system.
posts.title: Works now!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
It is mostly done as a matter of crossed wires. But I've added the
feature where commits are posted as blog entries to the apps page.
Not entirely intentional. But I was already down that rabbit hole
so I kept going. I'll make the appropriate changes soon to move the
git commit auto blogging over to the dev log page, which I've yet
to make. ^^;

But it's progress! The site is starting to have some idea of the
content that I want in it available. And I'm slowly starting to
understand how to piece it all together. It is my first flask app
after all. Man, never thought I'd be making web apps. I suppose I
never really fancied myself as a mobile developer either. But here
we are. Making kivy and flask apps.

TO THE KING!
posts.title: Apps now are devlogs! Wait.

the NFS mount not being quite as clever as I want.
